comments.commentBody:
Yes the GOP has lots of big spenders, and even though they try to project themselves as the party of Puritan morality, the girls on the strip will be waiting for them.
Just wait until thees delegates get a chance to compare their conservative overfed wives, with the LV ladies.

The median income in 1978 was $20,428. Which is a little over $90,000 today.  Today's median income is a little over $50,000. What happened to the rest?  It all went to those who got the capital gains tax cuts in the tax reform act of 1986.

The article begins by quoting from John Maynard Keynes: " ... the failure to provide for full employment and its arbitrary and inequitable distribution of wealth and incomes.” It is the "economic society" that is at fault here?
The fact is, it's just because they have stopped believing that an economy can reset itself better than the govt. can micromanage it. We have yet to see any reset, just because people do in fact operate on basis of the money motive to a great degree.

We have more of the unemployed now, and those even worse of than those recently laid off, in that they never may have had any lucrative work. And just because of the wonderful help the government affords those who otherwise couldn't afford much, those people have left the job market, perhaps for good. They have found alternative styles of living, namely living off the rest of the people ... in fact however, that has not even been possible, because they are living on basis of continued printing of money, so called National Deficit .
They are hardly guilty of what has happened here, yet the sad thing is that parasitism is doing fine today. ...It's even worse than nepotism!

This happened when it wasn't even necessary. Congress has failed miserably in finding a system of taxation which can handle the times we live in, with its propensity to outsourcing and automation. Tax the companies that are profiting so much using automation, to subsidize workers in industries not so 'blessed' with that.

What kind of economic society do we want and should expect from the people who represent us? That's the question. We supposedly all agree on a progressive tax structure, at least the people do. So I say make sure it happens. It should be expected that all people no matter what the source of income should pay into medicare and ss. It should be expected that corporations who make and sell in this country pay for that ability and the use of the nations resources. Taxes should be spent to create a "more perfect union". And we should have a set of laws to keep people from abusing the laws of this land. It is not too much to ask.
Republicans do not agree with any of this. I say they need to change their thinking or be dismissed from the political arena by the people they are suppose to represent.

Inequality is the correct focus. Jobs is only one aspect of the entire inequality picture. Shamefully it’s necessary to state jobs should pay a livable wage. So far, we’re creating mostly low income jobs.

We also suffer from inequality in access to uniformly good quality education with costs heaped on parents and students, access to food and food information that gives quality nutrition, and access to reasonable transportation to all these in highly congested metropolitan areas.

We have vast inequality in the anxiety of the nation’s workforce. For five years, most of the work force has been coerced into a state of anxiety about job loss, lack of pay raises, lack of advancement, forced early retirement, jobs being off-shored, moved to cheap-labor states, or automated out of existence. The generation of recent college grads is anxious about a meager future.

Coupled into that anxiety is the vague message workers should fear taking vacation time for fear of job loss.

A point FDR made in his 1936 Labor Day address was that economic freedom must be coupled with political freedom if the political freedom is to be worthwhile.

Or, as John Steinbeck pointed out in, “Of Mice and Men,” we are free to the extent we control our time and have money to pursue our personal desires. That message is the real reason the UK Minister of Education attacked the book as being of insufficient length.

Fairness is in the hands of “we the people.” This election is when we must fight back.
Too little, too late.  If in 2004, Coke had begun sales that donated one cent per can or bottle towards global warming, or had global warming themes on its cans, then we would have had something.

Agreed.  Judith Curry, one of the best Atmospheric Scientists in the world, recently told Congress that we cannot know the impacts of global warming because the climate models are not good enough.  As a PhD Atmospheric Scientist, I concur.  It's real, but we don't have any idea if the impacts will be good, bad or irrelevant.

"It's real, but we don't have any idea if the impacts will be good, bad or irrelevant."

That is the paradigmatic position of the lukewarmer, a species of AGW denier. Lukewarmers accept that warming is real, and even that humans are responsible, but aren't concerned because they don't expect to be affected much themselves, and they don't care about the poor people who will be.

Academic Refugee cites JA Curry, who is one of the tiny minority of working, publishing climate scientists that have made their reputations by disagreeing with the consensus of their colleagues. The U.S. National Academy of Sciences, not known for magical thinking, says this:

"Climate change is occurring, is very likely caused primarily by the emission of greenhouse gases from human activities, and poses significant risks for a range of human and natural systems. Emissions continue to increase, which will result in further change and greater risks. In the judgment of this report's authoring committee, the environmental, economic, and humanitarian risks posed by climate change indicate a pressing need for substantial action to limit the magnitude of climate change and to prepare for adapting to its impacts."

http://dels.nas.edu/Report/America-Climate-Choices-2011/12781

Readers should decide for themselves who has greater credibility: the tiny minority of scientific "skeptics" like Curry, or the overwhelming consensus represented by our country's most prestigious scientific body.

"Climate change" may be real but the imagined impacts are, magical thinking. To postulate that a change in average temperature of a couple of tenths of a degree is disrupting sugar supplies is patently absurd.

This is really really good news.  No matter how we feel about it, we are a market-based society and we know the market could be extremely efficient at transitioning our society from fossil fuels to renewables.  If doing so is better for major companies' bottom lines, that will happen faster.  And that will be better for all of us.

For capitalism to succeed markets need to expand. This means we all need to consume more resources.  Resources are limited so this model is unsustainable. Simply put, Coke is a waste of water just as over consumption is a waste of resources. The earth belongs to all living things and the only way to save it is through democratic control and democratic planning. This is ultimately the "inconvenient truth" that we all have to face.

What's interesting is that the entities with the largest global reach are the most sensitive to climate change. This makes perfect sense - they're averaging over the largest area.  While the weather in any one city, state, or even country is subject to natural variability, companies with global reach would have to contend with planet-wide changes in weather  - which is what climate change science indicates we're facing.

The important point is not the release of bottled-up (no pun intended) frustration, but the realignment of the players.  Coke et al. will inevitably seek to level the playing field with its competitors, by putting pressure (á la Citizens United) on Congress and elsewhere to seek regulation to force its competitors to incur the same costs which they are now externalizing on the environment.

Only when businesses outspend and politically out muscle the the big polluters, such as the $100 billion Koch brothers fossil fuel empire, and the biggest coal burners on the planet (The United states coal industry & coal fired power plants) and the much bigger Chinese coal burning dictatorship) will there be a reduction in carbon emissions, and any hope of reducing climate change problems, such as regions losing water resources, and rising ocean levels.

Thanks for the good intentions, Bruce, but you're sadly misinformed about the carbon tax, and about the effectiveness of positive vs. negative incentives. also about the notion that corporations are the source of the problem - we're all contributing to it, and we should all pay for some good approximation of the damage we cause. That's what a carbon tax would do (and is doing right now in BC, Canada).

A tax at roughly the right level would eliminate the need for lots of complicated, ineffective, sometimes counterproductive nonsense, including vehicle efficiency standards, carbon footprint calculations, etc..

Please read The Climate Casino (2013), by William Nordhaus if you really care to be informed about this.

The Carbon should be taxed so it stays in the ground. The higher the tax the less desirable it will be to mine it, pump it up or frack it out.

The revenues should be used to increase availability of renewable energy sources: solar, wind, hydrogen, water, nuclear and scrap carbon utilization (bio-fuels).

Imports from other countries who are not taxing Carbon in a similar manner, should be taxed upon entry into the US.

Keeping as much Carbon trapped in the ground as possible will help the health of the planet and humans. Stabilizing our environment has to be done now, otherwise we will all be suffocated, starved and drown.

Re: "Any investment a company makes to reduce carbon emissions will have both an immediate negative impact on its bottom line with the results benefiting its competitors" Not necessarily. The replacement of conventional motors with Variable Speed Drives often has a fairly fast payback and lowers operating costs. The same is true for some measures to improve the thermal efficiencies of buildings.

Outstanding! Bravo!

The battle against climate change cannot solely be waged on the field profit driven capitalism. Any investment a company makes to reduce carbon emissions will have both an immediate negative impact on its bottom line with the results benefiting its competitors. We will have to move beyond capitalism to a new global economic system that rewards process over profits. We have to develop a new metric that assigns prosperity to processes that reduce carbon emissions instead of just making the cheapest goods. Otherwise, there is no mechanism in pure capitalism to create the incentives for these kinds of investments.

Furthermore, this is global problem. We will have to develop trade organizations that dictate where we import goods from based upon associated carbon. Price can no longer be the sole factor.

A carbon tax is insufficient as it is a negative incentive that can be overcome with higher profits. We must move to a global system that gives preferential treatment to processes that reduce carbon regardless of profit.

I'm thinking outside the box here toward a permanent solution. So long as the cheapest energy rules, carbon fuels will reign supreme. All governments will have to get involved to develop a positive incentive based trade system to reduce emissions.

If Coca-Cola and others really want to help, they must use their financial clout to get politicians elected that will move toward these goals.

I much prefer Keynes' awkward phrase "arbitrary and inequitable distribution of wealth and income" to the laconic term "inequality."

In Keynes' phrase, the word "arbitrary" appears to mean based on personal whim without concern for what is fair or right, with the word "inequitable" also meaning unfair or unjust.

In contrast, the word "inequality" is a nebulous term more often used in the context of discrimination.

The Center on Budget Priorities notes that “two thirds of spending cuts proposed by Representative Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, would have come at the expense of lower-income families.” Yes, you are right Dr. Krugman, that the “tactics to worsen inequality” will cause a reaction. I find myself angry about the unfairness, lack of compassion, almost criminal austerity proposals.
My mother taught school for 30 years. She had former students request that their child be taught by her. She enjoyed the pride as children took their first book home to read to parents. Today, she and her nursing home rely in part on Medicaid. Her savings and real estate have all gone to her care. Now her social security and pension along with Medicaid funds pay for her continued care. Cut the Medicaid and what happens to children receiving medical care and elderly nursing home patients, and the nursing homes that depend on those subsidies?
I can’t imagine the hopeless situation many unemployed face. It upsets me that anti-abortion is a priority for the Republican Party when the born, Americans of all ages, need support. Cruel. Yes, the President needs to discuss inequality. It is intolerable that individuals and families already hurting be further squeezed by a mean spirited Congress.
This one took me forever. If there was another good guess for any of these words, I tried it first. Thank goodness for PROUDMARY.

Americans are not used to this type of treatment and hardship and will not respond well to having to forage for work. Given the chance they will sit it out and wait for the government to fix the problem.

Which is how we've come to this unholy alliance between government and the un- and under-employed. Government will continue to pay for unemployment, food stamps, etc., if people agree to wait for a miracle.

Ah, yes! The old "just move to where the jobs are" claim! Because everyone knows there are NO expenses associated with moving your family from one part of the country to another! And don't pay any attention to the fact that even in North Dakota there are STILL more applicants for every job than there are jobs to be had!

So easy, so simple! Why, you'd think someone might have already thought of it!
Tain't so.  The immigrants on primitive ships were few and many died.  Those millions came in the age of steamships and they left dire poverty or active persecution or both.

Any policy that chases "full employment" is destined to fail.

There is absolutely no economic rule or logic, that a given economic system needs to produce *exactly* the same number of jobs as the total work age population who desires to work. The very notion of trying to match two completely unrelated numbers is ludicrous.

The economy will provide exactly the number of workers that are need to satisfy internal and external demand, given all the economic constraints. In fact, we may advance our technology and production capacity so much, that it is like that less and less workers are needed to produce all the goods and services we can possibly consume.

History is replete with *the only viable solution* to excess workers. Migration. Be it the Irish and Italians migrating to America, or the Japanese migrating to Brazil, or Michigan residents migrating to Texas, or Greeks migrating to Germany. Workers who can't find work in one economic system need to migrate to another one.

Our economic policies should be about encouraging productivity improvements, production cost leadership, skills, entrepreneurship, and demand, so more jobs are created in the US than in other economies.

But there are no guarantees.

Can't find a job in Michigan or New York? Move to North Dakota (2% unemployment). And don't claim it is too hard to get on your car and drive 1,000 miles. Millions upon millions upon millions of immigrants, including our forefathers, crossed oceans in primitive ships.

What's holding Congress back from moving forward on global warming is *not* stupidity or ignorance,  or religious belief. It is corruption and greed. As long as the biggest donors are against doing anything nothing will be done.

Mr. Gilwood I think you are over rating the greed and corruption aspect of Congressional action or inaction. The Tea Party types are more ideologically driven in their stupidity and ignorance. I've watched Congressional  committee meetings where Republican Congressman have said that God would not permit climate change to happen to the United States. I will grant that corruption will always be a part of our Congress or almost any Congress but it is truly astounding to see the many ways that ignorance and stupidity reign in the U.S. Congress.

Corporations now are getting into climate change but Republicans are not. What will it take for the nay sayers to wake up to the reality of climate change. Early on I thought it would happen but the rapidity of the changes brought about by extra CO2 is stunning. The possibilities of methane being added to the climate change mix by the melting of the arctic permafrosts and the speeding up of climate change makes it imperative that we do something right now about the sources of the gases. Yet somehow there are Republicans in Congress who believe that God will not let the climate change. So the rest of us pay the price for their obstinate stupidity.
a carbon tax with the money immediately recycled towards purchases by individuals/businesses of green technology.  pay as you go, higher mpg, more solar.

" ...the idea of a price or tax on carbon pollution... "

Such nonsense. These advocates are focused on money and the present economic paradigm. In time their silly notions will fall to the wayside as biogeophysical phenomenon change, due to the human enterprise, swamps the enterprise and the notion of human control of nature recedes rapidly into the past as a funny notion of human dominance over Earth systems. Earth abides.

While I agree wholeheartedly that renewable energy is critical to stemming the effects of climate change (for those confusing the two, global warming is one effect of climate change, as is excessive cooling like the recent polar chill in the US), nuclear energy is NOT the answer and should not even be a consideration. It comes with a very potentially deadly side-effect: radiation. It is just as dangerous if not more so, than fossil fuel. Look no further than Fukushima. Follow the reports, listen to the interviews, listen and listen well to the people affected by the radiation in Japan. They're protesting right now against nuclear energy, but of course their voices aren't being heard, and the mainstream media isn't giving them their rightful airtime.

Radioactive elements are permanent and impossible to clean out. Save the environment? Not when a failed reactor spews millions of gallons of radiation into the sea, which will eventually travel the globe.

Above all please don't bring out the old "atoms for peace" propaganda—that's what the US used to coax the Japanese people to let the nuclear reactors into their country not too long after the horror of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Birgitte:

Please note that JW was speaking of nuclear fusion, not our present nuclear fission technology. Fusion, should it prove commercially viable, really does hold the promise of providing a great deal of energy with very little burden of nuclear waste, no radiation risk to miners, and essentially no risk of proliferating the materials used to make nuclear weapons.

The difficulty is that commercializing nuclear fusion is a very difficult task indeed. But see ITER for some hope:

http://www.iter.org/
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITER

We need business to see climate change as an opportunity. Renewable energy could become America's next export market. Think how our balance of payments would change if U.S. innovators harnessed nuclear fusion and shipped cheap, clean, and limitless power overseas. We could save the environment and our bottom line, too.

In 1944, America was desperate to harness the atom for war. We should be just as desperate to harness the atom for peace in 2014.

All the more reason to build a massive near-earth solar array in outer space. No atmospheric interference, 24-hour direct sun exposure year-round, no limitations based on real-estate, and it will create shade. Many possible modalities exist for transmitting the energy to earth. It would create jobs and help the environment and not mess with anyone's backyard.

Why build our own nuclear reactors when we have a better, safer, larger one already floating benignly out in space? With the financial and political backing of wealthy corporations like Coca-Cola, big ideas like this one have more chance of coming to pass.

Well isn't Exxon -Mobil already investing in other fuel sources? Which perhaps may not be at the pace to your preference.

Also do not be fooled that alternative sources do not come with hidden costs (and I mean dollars). For example, most if not all electric cars to day there is a hefty fee when having to have the batteries replaced, which I 've heard averaging around $10,000 give or take a few thousand. This comes with either leasing or buying in one shape or form. I not here to bash these cars, but these fees should be more known to the consumer.

Great.
Industry knows, scientists know, the military knows, and the media is beginning to know (thanks for recent pieces on this critical subject, NYT).
Now, if we can just get it through to the thick skulls in congress: Climate change is here, now, and will ruin our planet if we don't fight it with everything we've got.
Support a revenue-neutral carbon tax, and tell congress you intend to vote any flat-earther or anti-science wind-bag right out of office. This is our only planet, and it's way past time we started acting like it.

In the end no matter what the reasons are to encourage corporations to acknowledge the impacts and relationship between global environment and business, if it improves the chances to improve the environment, so be it if they can still make a quadrillion dollars..
